sentences.sentence: Scott Morrison's "miracle" election win in 2019 appeared to draw a line under the political madness that had marred the previous decade in Canberra.
The stunning victory, against the opinion polls and the odds, gave Mr Morrison great moral authority.
But politics is ultimately a numbers game.
The Coalition's 77 seats gave it a wafer-thin majority in the 151-seat House.
The defection to the crossbench by Craig Kelly has robbed the Coalition of its narrow working majority.

Alas, for the national interest - and for the job prospects of 878,000 unemployed Australians - this makes it even more unlikely the Morrison government will rise to the reform challenge posed by a once-in-a-century global pandemic crisis.In reality, the Prime Minister never forgot his slender victory margin - nor the "quiet Australians" responsible for the win.
Hence his government's pre-crisis reluctance to push major tax or workplace reform to boost sluggish growth, productivity and wage levels.
Hence Mr Morrison's ruling out of a supply-side agenda to turbocharge the economic recovery.

This has emboldened Labor's shaky leader, Anthony Albanese, to seek refuge in a pro-union "job security" platform that would make more jobs insecure and undermine the next stage of recovery.A cluster of events has put the focus in Canberra back on personalities rather than policy.

Mr Kelly's defection means the Prime Minister will no longer be tangled up in the controversy over the MP's Facebook posts about unconventional COVID-19 treatments and vaccine equivocation amid the national vaccination rollout that promises to restore something approaching normal life.
Mr Kelly says he will support supply, confidence and any legislation for which the government has a 2019 election mandate.
But the loss of its majority gives the Morrison government an alibi of sorts for continuing to take the line of least political resistance on reform and the recovery.
Especially when this has emboldened the rural populist rump, from Bob Katter to Barnaby Joyce and George Christensen.
The rebel Nationals led by Mr Joyce and Matt Canavan are pushing for government-built coal-fired power plants that the private sector would never risk financing.

And Mr Kelly first rose from obscurity as a climate change sceptic on Sky News "after dark".The parliamentary instability complicates the Prime Minister's move to the centre on climate and energy, getting behind gas to keep the lights on, backing technology to cut emissions, and edging towards a net zero target by 2050 to anchor Australia's carbon abatement transition.

Meanwhile, Labor's climate and energy position has been thrown into confusion by the revolt on its right flank led by Joel Fitzgibbon.Serious issues of workplace culture and safety inside the "Canberra bubble" have been exposed by the shocking rape allegations from former Liberal staffer Brittany Higgins.
At the centre of the debate should be how best to protect the integrity of the institution and the safety of all who work there.
Instead, it has descended into a partisan "who knew what and when" blame game in search of a political scalp.

The pressure forced Defence Minister Linda Reynolds yesterday to take leave from her post due to ill health, cancel an address to the National Press Club, and pull out of a crunch meeting with the French contractor for the troubled $90 billion future submarine program.

This is happening as Australia confronts the greatest strategic uncertainty in our region since the 1930s.There are legitimate questions for Senator Reynolds - and for other government members and staff - to answer about the treatment of Ms Higgins.
But what makes the revival of political games as usual so hard to stomach is the lack of will to face up to reform challenges.
Yes, Australia has done well to suppress the virus.
Yes, the largely reopened economy has bounced back on pent-up and pumped-up demand relying on cheap money.
And yes, we are pinning our comeback hopes on the vaccines.
But what has also come flooding back is the political-class complacency in Canberra that will handicap Australia's ability to make the strongest possible recovery from COVID-19.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: Scott Morrison's "miracle" election win in 2019 appeared to draw a line under the political madness that had marred the previous decade in Canberra. The stunning victory, against the opinion polls and the odds, gave Mr Morrison great moral authority. But politics is ultimately a numbers game. The Coalition's 77 seats gave it a wafer-thin majority in the 151-seat House. The defection to the crossbench by Craig Kelly has robbed the Coalition of its narrow working majority. Alas, for the national interest - and for the job prospects of 878,000 unemployed Australians - this makes it even more unlikely the Morrison government will rise to the reform challenge posed by a once-in-a-century global pandemic crisis.In reality, the Prime Minister never forgot his slender victory margin - nor the "quiet Australians" responsible for the win. Hence his government's pre-crisis reluctance to push major tax or workplace reform to boost sluggish growth, productivity and wage levels. Hence Mr Morrison's ruling out of a supply-side agenda to turbocharge the economic recovery. This has emboldened Labor's shaky leader, Anthony Albanese, to seek refuge in a pro-union "job security" platform that would make more jobs insecure and undermine the next stage of recovery.A cluster of events has put the focus in Canberra back on personalities rather than policy. Mr Kelly's defection means the Prime Minister will no longer be tangled up in the controversy over the MP's Facebook posts about unconventional COVID-19 treatments and vaccine equivocation amid the national vaccination rollout that promises to restore something approaching normal life. Mr Kelly says he will support supply, confidence and any legislation for which the government has a 2019 election mandate. But the loss of its majority gives the Morrison government an alibi of sorts for continuing to take the line of least political resistance on reform and the recovery. Especially when this has emboldened the rural populist rump, from Bob Katter to Barnaby Joyce and George Christensen. The rebel Nationals led by Mr Joyce and Matt Canavan are pushing for government-built coal-fired power plants that the private sector would never risk financing. And Mr Kelly first rose from obscurity as a climate change sceptic on Sky News "after dark".The parliamentary instability complicates the Prime Minister's move to the centre on climate and energy, getting behind gas to keep the lights on, backing technology to cut emissions, and edging towards a net zero target by 2050 to anchor Australia's carbon abatement transition. At the centre of the debate should be how best to protect the integrity of the institution and the safety of all who work there. The pressure forced Defence Minister Linda Reynolds yesterday to take leave from her post due to ill health, cancel an address to the National Press Club, and pull out of a crunch meeting with the French contractor for the troubled $90 billion future submarine program. Yes, the largely reopened economy has bounced back on pent-up and pumped-up demand relying on cheap money. And yes, we are pinning our comeback hopes on the vaccines. But what has also come flooding back is the political-class complacency in Canberra that will handicap Australia's ability to make the strongest possible recovery from COVID-19.
